story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising.

With everything going on at the moment it's hard not to focus on COVID19 - something that affects us all. However it's worth remembering that there are still other deadly diseases out there. It is estimated that there are currently around 4 million people in the UK living with a cancer diagnosis and each year about 164,000 people die from cancer. That's about 3.4 times the current death toll from COVID19.

Like everyone in the hospital, Macmillan have continued to provide amazing support to many people affected by cancer despite all the additional challenges the 'Rona virus brings.

There's a lot going on at the moment and times are hard for all but Macmillan are such a big part of so many people's cancer journey that it's easy to forget that they are a charity and survive on donations. For this reason I'm trying to do my own little bit to raise money for Macmillan by growing a ridiculous moustache during November. story:
Thank you for supporting Len Moyle’s fundraising page. 

Len and his wife Jean have a longstanding history of raising money for charity. Known throughout Cornwall as the ‘real’ Father Christmas, Len has grown his beard and dressed up as Father Christmas for the last 30 years – visiting children in schools throughout the county to keep the magic of Christmas alive whilst raising valuable funds for local charities, including the Merlin Centre, Children’s Hospice South West, Cornwall Muscular Dystrophy and Cornwall Air Ambulance. 

Some of you may also recognise Len from Cornwall Gold where he appears as Father Christmas in their Santa’s Grotto. When finding out about Len’s illness they said: “We are going to miss Len this year, he has quite the fan base! He is so wonderful with the children, always makes time to see as many as he can.”

Sadly, Len was diagnosed with lung cancer earlier this year and is currently undergoing treatment, however it hasn’t stopped him wanting to continue his lifetime’s work of raising money for charity and this year his sponsored beard shave is in aid of Macmillan Cancer Support.

The charity is there to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. 

Usually Len and his wife Jean would be out in the community to raise money, however due to lockdown and Len’s ill health, that isn’t possible this year so they are asking for donations through JustGiving. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. They'll never sell your details or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, your money will be sent directly to the charity, so it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

So please give what you can to support Len and this amazing charity. Thank you so much!

story:
*The story behind the fundraising *

On the 30th of July 2020 my Dad, Colin, recieved the most devastating news, he was told he had stage 4 incurable aggressive cancer. This news came as a total shock to him and the whole family and coming to terms with the reality has, and continues to be an emotional rollercoaster for everybody but most of all my Dad who continues to puts on a brave face each and every day. 

Shortly after his diagnosis, my Dad started chemotherapy to try to shrink the numerous cancers and give him more time. Throughout the past few months my Dad has gone through numerous rounds of chemotherapy and health complications due to the side effects. He has gone through all this in the midst of a global pandemic which meant he has attended his consultant appointments alone, chemo alone, he has shielded in the same 4 walls for months, he has missed out on precious time with family and friends and making memories due to lockdown and the restrictions. Even with all this he still has fight in his heart and shows pure determination. He continues to fight so hard mentally and physically every day to not let the big 'C' beat him. He's a true hero and I couldn't be prouder.

He has now completed his chemotherapy and the results have been as positive as they can be. He has been given extra time that without the chemotherapy, he would not have. He will continue to undergo specialist treatment to try and suppress the cancer as much as possible which, although there is no guarantee on the affectiveness of the treatment, it can potentially give my Dad more time to live his life to the fullest. I am so very thankful for this, I get to make memories with my Dad and cherish every day with him. (Well, once lockdown is over) . Its true, you don't realise who and what you take for granted until life turns things upside down and you are faced with a heartbreaking reality. 

I would give anything for a miraculous cure for my Dad. We as a family will continue to be positive and hopeful that he will remain in as good health as possible for as long as possible. Thanks to Macmillan, we have been able to get a better understanding of my Dads condition and ways to help and support him and us. Macmillan provide vital resources from recipes for food to eat during chemo, to user friendly information sheets on treatments, medication, side effects, advice, support and so much more. Each time my Dad went to his Chemo he was made to feel at ease by the amazing NHS staff and macmillan nurses who treated him. There is so much more Macmillan do that I'm sure over time we as a family will make use of and without fundraising and donations this wouldn't be possible.

So, in order to encourage my Dad to get active and also raise awareness and funds for Macmillan at the same time, We have made a pact that each day starting from the 9th of November 2020, for 40 days that myself, my Mum and my Dad will do some form of fitness/excersize each day. I will be aiming to complete a range of workouts and runs to push myself each day. My Mums aim is to get more active, go on walks and prioritise time for excersize each day. My Dads aim is to do non exhursive exersize on his good days and keep as active as possible each day (On my Dads bad days I will do double, lets hope there's not to many of these). By doing this I hope it gives my Dad a focus each day and help his, my Mums and my mental and physical health. 

If you wish to donate to this extremely worthwhile and needed charity through our go fund me page, we would be very greatful! 

Hold your loved ones just that little bit tighter and appreciate every second, because you never know whats round the corner ❤

story:
As some of you know, Harman was born with a congenital heart disease called Tetrology of Fallot. ToF consists of four defects of the heart including a ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary valve stenosis, a misplaced aorta and a thickened right ventricular wall. We were very lucky that they discovered it at the very early stages during pregnancy, but others are not so lucky and only becomes apparent once the baby is born. Eventually he will have an operation to rectify this. 

The donation target is only a small amount but the money raised will go to British Heart Foundation. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like you that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. Monica and I would greatly appreciate any sort of donation that you're able to give.

Lots of love, the Rayatts x

pageSummaryWhat: Raising money on behalf of our beloved Derek
story:
We are raising money on behalf of our beloved husband, father, brother and friend Derek, who sadly was taken from us prematurely due to unknown complications of cardio vascular disease. 

Derek was a charismatic, loveable and infectious person, who touched a lot of people's heart with his warming personality. He was the absolute life and soul and was able to light up any room he walked into. He would always put others first and will be greatly missed by everyone. 

The family want to extend their gratitude to the Midlands Air Ambulance who worked tirelessly to save Derek's life, but unfortunately on this occasion were unable to. As the Air Ambulance rely solely on private funding, we want to raise as much as we can for this amazing charity so they are able to continue in their efforts to help save other people’s lives. We also want to donate half of the money raised to the British Heart Foundation, so they are able to continue their research into heart and circulatory diseases. 

Any donation is greatly appreciated. 

Thank you 

From the Wilkinson family x

eventName: Running 165km in a month for Cancer Research UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Unfortunately, cancer has had an immeasurable effect on my family over the years, as it has on many other families all over the world. On average, 450 people die of cancer in the UK every day which accumulates to a horrifying 165,000 deaths a year. Therefore, starting on the 9th of November, I am aiming to run 165km (102.5 miles) in the space of one month (30 days) in order to raise money for Cancer Research UK. 

Cancer Research UK are a charity that run pioneering research in the hope to bring forward the day that all cancers can be cured, and many cancer sufferers are alive today as a result of their tireless work. They do not receive government funding so this life-saving research is only possible as a result of peoples’ charitable donations, and even small donations can make a huge difference. So please feel free to sponsor me in this challenge and donate whatever you can as it will all go to this amazing cause. 

I am extremely grateful for your support and any amount you can give 🤍

story:
The last two years Eliza has worn a different Christmas outfit every day in December bringing much joy to those who see our daily pictures on Facebook.

It started in 2018 as a way to remember my mom who died suddenly when I was 16 weeks pregnant.  Mom loved Christmas so much. 

In 2019 we did it to raise funds for my best friend who was diagnosed with terminal cancer in June 2019. We hoped to raise funds for her to create memories with her two daughters. Sadly Natasha lost her fight on 22nd December 2019.  The money we raised was given to her daughters to make new happy memories. 

In 2020 , a very strange year, we hope to raise funds for Cancer Research in memory of Natasha and also for our friend Yvonne who was diagnosed with an aggressive breast cancer earlier this year.  On top of dealing with life in 2020, Yvonne has had a mastectomy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and isolation from friends and family all while still leading her SlimmingWorld groups and supporting hundreds of people through such a difficult time.  

Hopefully the funds we raise will help beat cancer.

pageSummary: Trekking Mount Kilimanjaro for Marie Curie
pageSummaryWhat: Trekking Mount Kilimanjaro for Marie Curie
story:
In September 2021 I will be trekking Mount Kilimanjaro over the course of 10 days. I am climbing for Marie Curie; a charity that provides palliative care and support to those with life limiting illness, and their family and friends.

1 in 2 people in the UK born after 1960 will be diagnosed with some form of cancer during their lifetime, with around 165,000 cancer deaths in the UK a year. This accounts for around 28% of total deaths yearly. Although shocking, these statistics are the reality that many people unfairly have to face today. Marie Curie is one of many charities that can make these harsh realities just a little bit less scary. 

The love and support that Marie Curie nurses offer to thousands of families around the UK is indescribable, many aren't able to cope without them. With cancer being an illness close to so many people's hearts, including my own, I believe that Marie Curie deserve all the help they can get, which is why I've chosen to fundraise for them. 

Please help me to give back to the charity that has done so much for those who need it most by donating!

pageSummaryWhat: Hi Folks! I'm running and fundraising
story:
Dear reader,

The global pandemic has been disrupting our modes of life for months now, and once again the most innocent among us have been severely affected: I am talking about children. I do not mean to sound overly dramatic - I will leave that rhetoric to some crybaby politicians, and stick to my straightforward communication style instead... So, let's face reality: because of this virus, children around the world have been affected in multiple ways. 

In a direct way, the virus could result in loss of parental care due to death, illness or separation, thereby placing children at heightened risk for violence, neglect or exploitation. More indirectly, many of the prevention and control measures have resulted in disruptions to the reporting and referral mechanisms of child protection services. For children in residential care, a lack of capacity and resources has resulted in a rapid closure of such facilities, with children being returned to families without proper preparation. For children in street situations, access to help and support services is likely to be even more challenging. Moreover, measures to contain the virus have affected delivery of vital support and treatment services as well as contact with informal support networks. And these are just some aspects of a broader dynamic that can't be narrowed down to a few lines. For this reason I will share some links at the bottom of the page, please do inform yourself on what is going on.

So what? To put it simply, this means that more children need more help now, our help. 

Under lockdown, while studying and working in front of a screen, I often found my mind lingering on the following dilemma: "What can I do to overcome the current limitations and significantly help those affected children?". If before the pandemic I could easily volunteer and pioneer for children's rights in a variety of ways as I have often done, the current restrictions have made it way more challenging to reach out to those in need. Thus I realised that I would have had to make the best out of the only two tools still available to fundraise,  which are internet and about one hour of outdoor exercise per day (aka my daily spark of joy) to contribute to an initiative that will be life changing for many children. 

This is how I decided to run the 2021 Royal Parks Half Marathon and fundraise for Unicef. Unicef needs our help to support children around the world. Your donation will help to provide children life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection. Help me smash their fundraising targets and help children worldwide! 

Your donation will make a difference, just as every single vote in the latest American presidential election has lead to a great milestone for democracy and gender equality. Please become a part of this donation now by contributing with what ever you can to my fundraiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. 

Thank you. 

Sincerely,

Rebecca
